trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to deploy an Azure Virtual Machine Scale Set using a Visual Studio Resource Group Deployment.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to deploy an Azure Virtual Machine Scale Set using a Visual Studio Resource Group Deployment.

trans-unit.source: [Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/azure-vm-scale-sets-public-preview/) are an Azure Compute resource to deploy and manage a collection of similar virtual machines with easily integrated options for auto-scale and load balancing.
trans-unit.target: [Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/azure-vm-scale-sets-public-preview/) are an Azure Compute resource to deploy and manage a collection of similar virtual machines with easily integrated options for auto-scale and load balancing.

trans-unit.source: You can provision and deploy VM Scale Sets using [Azure Resource Manager (ARM) Templates](https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates).
trans-unit.target: You can provision and deploy VM Scale Sets using [Azure Resource Manager (ARM) Templates](https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates).

trans-unit.source: ARM Templates can be deployed using Azure CLI, PowerShell, REST and also directly from Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: ARM Templates can be deployed using Azure CLI, PowerShell, REST and also directly from Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides a set of example Templates which can be deployed as part of an Azure Resource Group Deployment project.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides a set of example Templates which can be deployed as part of an Azure Resource Group Deployment project.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Group deployments are a way to group together and publish a set of related Azure resources in a single deployment operation.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Group deployments are a way to group together and publish a set of related Azure resources in a single deployment operation.

trans-unit.source: You can learn more about them here: [Creating and deploying Azure resource groups through Visual Studio](../vs-azure-tools-resource-groups-deployment-projects-create-deploy/).
trans-unit.target: You can learn more about them here: [Creating and deploying Azure resource groups through Visual Studio](../vs-azure-tools-resource-groups-deployment-projects-create-deploy/).

trans-unit.source: Pre-requisites
trans-unit.target: Pre-requisites

trans-unit.source: To get started deploying VM Scale Sets in Visual Studio you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To get started deploying VM Scale Sets in Visual Studio you need the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 or 2015
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 or 2015

trans-unit.source: Azure SDK 2.7 or 2.8
trans-unit.target: Azure SDK 2.7 or 2.8

trans-unit.source: Note: These instructions assume you are using Visual Studio 2015 with [Azure SDK 2.8](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/announcing-the-azure-sdk-2-8-for-net/).
trans-unit.target: Note: These instructions assume you are using Visual Studio 2015 with [Azure SDK 2.8](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/announcing-the-azure-sdk-2-8-for-net/).

trans-unit.source: Creating a Project
trans-unit.target: Creating a Project

trans-unit.source: Create a new project in Visual Studio 2015 by choosing **File | New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: Create a new project in Visual Studio 2015 by choosing **File | New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: File New
trans-unit.target: File New

trans-unit.source: Under **Visual C# | Cloud**, choose **Azure Resource Manager** to create a project for deploying an ARM Template.
trans-unit.target: Under **Visual C# | Cloud**, choose **Azure Resource Manager** to create a project for deploying an ARM Template.

trans-unit.source: Create Project
trans-unit.target: Create Project

trans-unit.source: From the list of Templates, select either the Linux or Windows Virtual Machine Scale Set Template.
trans-unit.target: From the list of Templates, select either the Linux or Windows Virtual Machine Scale Set Template.

trans-unit.source: Select Template
trans-unit.target: Select Template

trans-unit.source: Once your project is created you’ll see PowerShell deployment scripts, an Azure Resource Manager Template, and a parameter file for the Virtual Machine Scale Set.
trans-unit.target: Once your project is created you’ll see PowerShell deployment scripts, an Azure Resource Manager Template, and a parameter file for the Virtual Machine Scale Set.

trans-unit.source: Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Customize your project
trans-unit.target: Customize your project

trans-unit.source: Now you can edit the Template to customize it for your application's needs, such as adding VM extension properties or editing load balancing rules.
trans-unit.target: Now you can edit the Template to customize it for your application's needs, such as adding VM extension properties or editing load balancing rules.

trans-unit.source: By default the VM Scale Set Templates are configured to deploy the AzureDiagnostics extension which makes it easy to add autoscale rules.
trans-unit.target: By default the VM Scale Set Templates are configured to deploy the AzureDiagnostics extension which makes it easy to add autoscale rules.

trans-unit.source: It also deploys a load balancer with a public IP address, configured with inbound NAT rules which let you connect to the VM instances with SSH (Linux) or RDP (Windows) – the front end port range starts at 50000, which means in the case of Linux, if you SSH to port 50000 of the public IP address (or domain name) you will be routed to port 22 of the first VM in the Scale Set.
trans-unit.target: It also deploys a load balancer with a public IP address, configured with inbound NAT rules which let you connect to the VM instances with SSH (Linux) or RDP (Windows) – the front end port range starts at 50000, which means in the case of Linux, if you SSH to port 50000 of the public IP address (or domain name) you will be routed to port 22 of the first VM in the Scale Set.

trans-unit.source: Connecting to port 50001 will be routed to port 22 of the second VM and so on.
trans-unit.target: Connecting to port 50001 will be routed to port 22 of the second VM and so on.

trans-unit.source: A good way to edit your Templates with Visual Studio is to use the JSON Outline to organize the parameters, variables and resources.
trans-unit.target: A good way to edit your Templates with Visual Studio is to use the JSON Outline to organize the parameters, variables and resources.

trans-unit.source: With an understanding of the schema Visual Studio can point out errors in your Template before you deploy it.
trans-unit.target: With an understanding of the schema Visual Studio can point out errors in your Template before you deploy it.

trans-unit.source: JSON Explorer
trans-unit.target: JSON Explorer

trans-unit.source: Deploy the project
trans-unit.target: Deploy the project

trans-unit.source: Deploy the ARM Template to Azure to create the VM Scale Set resource.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the ARM Template to Azure to create the VM Scale Set resource.

trans-unit.source: Right click on the project node, choose **Deploy | New Deployment**.
trans-unit.target: Right click on the project node, choose **Deploy | New Deployment**.

trans-unit.source: Deploy Template
trans-unit.target: Deploy Template

trans-unit.source: Select your subscription in the “Deploy to Resource Group” dialog.
trans-unit.target: Select your subscription in the “Deploy to Resource Group” dialog.

trans-unit.source: Deploy Template
trans-unit.target: Deploy Template

trans-unit.source: From here you can also create a new Azure Resource Group to deploy your Template to.
trans-unit.target: From here you can also create a new Azure Resource Group to deploy your Template to.

trans-unit.source: New Resource Group
trans-unit.target: New Resource Group

trans-unit.source: Next select the **Edit Parameters** button to enter parameters which will be passed to your Template, Certain values such as the username and password for the OS are required to create the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Next select the **Edit Parameters** button to enter parameters which will be passed to your Template, Certain values such as the username and password for the OS are required to create the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Edit Parameters
trans-unit.target: Edit Parameters

trans-unit.source: Now click **Deploy**.
trans-unit.target: Now click **Deploy**.

trans-unit.source: The **Output** window will show the deployment progress.
trans-unit.target: The **Output** window will show the deployment progress.

trans-unit.source: Note that the the action is executing the **Deploy-AzureResourceGroup.ps1** script.
trans-unit.target: Note that the the action is executing the **Deploy-AzureResourceGroup.ps1** script.

trans-unit.source: Output Window
trans-unit.target: Output Window

trans-unit.source: Exploring your VM Scale Set
trans-unit.target: Exploring your VM Scale Set

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment completes, you can view the new VM Scale Set in the Visual Studio **Cloud Explorer** (refresh the list).
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment completes, you can view the new VM Scale Set in the Visual Studio **Cloud Explorer** (refresh the list).

trans-unit.source: Cloud Explorer lets you manage Azure resources in Visual Studio while developing applications.
trans-unit.target: Cloud Explorer lets you manage Azure resources in Visual Studio while developing applications.

trans-unit.source: You can also view your VM Scale Set in the Azure Portal and Azure Resource Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can also view your VM Scale Set in the Azure Portal and Azure Resource Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Cloud Explorer
trans-unit.target: Cloud Explorer

trans-unit.source: The portal provides the best way to visually manage your Azure infrastructure with a web browser, while Azure Resource Explorer provides an easy way to explorer and debug Azure resources, giving a window into the “instance view” and also showing PowerShell commands for the resources you are looking at.
trans-unit.target: The portal provides the best way to visually manage your Azure infrastructure with a web browser, while Azure Resource Explorer provides an easy way to explorer and debug Azure resources, giving a window into the “instance view” and also showing PowerShell commands for the resources you are looking at.

trans-unit.source: While VM Scale Sets are in preview, the Resource Explorer will show the most detail for your VM Scale Sets.
trans-unit.target: While VM Scale Sets are in preview, the Resource Explorer will show the most detail for your VM Scale Sets.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve successfully deployed VM Scale Sets through Visual Studio you can further customize your project to suit your application requirements.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve successfully deployed VM Scale Sets through Visual Studio you can further customize your project to suit your application requirements.

trans-unit.source: For example setting up autoscale by adding an Insights resource, adding infrastructure to your Template like standalone VMs, or deploying applications using the custom script extension.
trans-unit.target: For example setting up autoscale by adding an Insights resource, adding infrastructure to your Template like standalone VMs, or deploying applications using the custom script extension.

trans-unit.source: A good source of example Templates can be found in the [Azure Quickstart Templates](https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates) GitHub repository (search for "vmss").
trans-unit.target: A good source of example Templates can be found in the [Azure Quickstart Templates](https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates) GitHub repository (search for "vmss").
